awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Operations of VERITAS in the Epoch 2019 to 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation.  Observations of astrophysical gamma rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe, can be used to test fundamental physics, and play a key role in multi-messenger astrophysics. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is a ground-based observatory designed to study high energy gamma rays.  VERITAS has unique capabilities, providing high sensitivity pointed observations of both galactic and extragalactic sources.  This award provides funding to continue VERITAS operations.  During this time the Observatory will implement a program designed to address key science drivers in Galactic and extragalactic physics, as well as themes in multi-messenger and time-domain astrophysics. This award also provides resources to initially operate a novel prototype telescope co-located with VERITAS and will be used to verify its performance and optimize its final design. This prototype is intended for use in the next-generation gamma-ray observatory, the Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA).  This award will also support the VERITAS collaboration efforts to engage the public in science. These include collaboration with the Whipple Observatory Visitors Center to promote VERITAS science to the public, other educators, museum professionals and the wider community.  
 
VERITAS is an array of four 12-meter atmospheric-Cherenkov telescopes. VERITAS seeks both to identify new sources of high energy gamma rays and to perform in-depth studies of the known sources to better understand their underlying fundamental processes. The VERITAS Galactic catalog includes supernova remnants, pulsars, binary systems, the Galactic Center and sources whose classification is unknown. VERITAS's  extragalactic catalog includes active galactic nuclei, radio galaxies, and starburst galaxies. VERITAS multi-messenger programs include searches for transient emission from sources associated with IceCube neutrino events, gamma-ray bursts and gravitational wave signals.  Beyond the source physics, VERITAS studies address questions related to dark matter, cosmic-ray origin and acceleration, and cosmology, among others.  This work directly addresses the goals of NSF's "Windows on the Universe: The Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics" Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
VERITAS is the world’s most-sensitive very-high-energy (VHE; E > 100 GeV) gamma-ray observatory, and is located in southern Arizona.  This award from the NSF partially supported the experimental operations of the VERITAS telescope array and the array facility for the purposes of astrophysical research from 2019-2023. The support covered the project’s thirteenth through sixteenth season of operation. This award also supported the initial operation of a prototype telescope for the next-generation gamma-ray observatory (CTA). VERITAS remains operational and in excellent condition and support is identified to operate the facility through at least 2025.
    An external review (NSF PA-CP) concluded VERITAS scientists “provided a compelling case for Very High Energy (VHE) gamma-ray observations, as key steps towards understanding the most energetic processes operating in the Universe”.  The scientific operation of VERITAS was very strong during the award period and another review (2021 VERITAS ESAC) stated it "was very impressed with the state of VERITAS in terms of science accomplishments, science plan, telescope operations and connection to the broader astronomy community.” Overall, the VERITAS collaboration has reported the detection of 65 astrophysical sources of VHE gamma rays. The VERITAS catalog increased during the award period, and it represents about one-quarter of the entire VHE catalog. All VERITAS results are published in high-impact factor, peer-reviewed journals. The VERITAS collaboration has published 132 refereed journal articles and has produced 79 PhD theses. Twenty-seven of these articles appeared, and 12 of these theses were completed, during the award period. While the science program addressed a number of important topics in astrophysics, Breakthrough results include the VERITAS discovery of VHE gamma-ray emission from the radio galaxy 3C 264 and the blazar S3 1227+25. Another key result was the detection of the Crab Nebula with a prototype Schwarzschild-Couder gamma-ray telescope co-located with VERITAS. The detection strongly leveraged simultaneous VERITAS observations and it validated this novel next-generation technology for the community. Another major highlight is the modernization of a an optical-astronomy technique dormant for ~5 decades (Stellar Intensity Interferometry) which enables VERITAS to measure stellar diameters with unprecedented precision. Dozens of VERITAS journal articles are in preparation, with another seven near submission or recently submitted. Significant science topics continue to be explored with VERITAS and observing time at VERITAS remains oversubscribed (by a factor of ~2). The training mission of VERITAS also remains strong as 35% of the collaboration members are students. The 2021 VERITAS ESAC also noted “VERITAS continues to be an invaluable scientific facility for VHE gamma-ray astronomy, providing excellent return on the cumulative investment to date from all sources.”
    During the award period, VERITAS experimental operations were also highly successful. The NSF PA-CP review commented that: “The VERITAS project has a history of effective and efficient management” and “has an excellent record of telescope uptime”. The project’s technical performance improved since the PA-CP review, with the many of most important performance metrics averaging to all-time bests. Specifically, an average of ~950 h of data were taken over the four seasons covered by this award (~1035 h excluding the pandemic shortened 2019-20 season). During this period all four telescopes were operational 97% of the time and fewer than 1% of the available time were lost due to technical reasons. These quantities surpass the project requirements of more than 900 h data per year, >90% four-telescope participation, and <10% time lost to technical issues. All other technical performance metrics for the VERITAS data were met and often exceeded and no event rendered any significant quantity of data unusable.
    Throughout this award the VERITAS collaboration continued its strong commitment to enabling public understanding of science as an outcome of its research.  At the VERITAS site itself, the F.L. Whipple Observatory (FLWO) Science Center coordinated activities to promote VERITAS science to the public. Here exhibits, videos and virtual-reality sessions presented astronomy and astrophysics relevant to VERITAS. VERITAS Project Office (VPO) scientists also hosted student internships, delivered public lectures and participated in the extensive community outreach program at FLWO. This included providing tours of the VERITAS site, hosting star parties, participating in science fairs, visiting classrooms and developing videos. During the pandemic closure of the Science Center in 2021, it was completely remodeled and new VERITAS/CTA exhibits were created for future visitors. A public website (http://veritas.sao.arizona.edu) operated by the VPO provided a description of the VERITAS project and related science. All refereed VERITAS publications and PhD theses are also linked to this page, along with a brief description of each result. Over the course of the award we also enabled many unique outreach experiences, including several iterations of VERITAS Muon Hunter partnership with the Zooniverse project. Approximately 20,000 volunteers have participated in this citizen science effort so far.
    The VERITAS collaboration is grateful for the support of the U.S. National Science Foundation which makes its research possible.
